wow.... that the first time I hear they make you memorize the periodic table....
@carlasouza5194  at high school level
@carlasouza5194  Yeah! For us its the first 30 - 40 elements on the periodic table, we also have to remember all constants from planck to Rydberg and every small detail.

@carlasouza5194   They really want to keep you dumb there in America, don't they? :q Memorizing the periodic table, or at least some portions of it that are relevant to organic chemistry isn't really that hard if you learn it piece by piece. E.g. the last column is the noble gases: He, Ne, Ar, Kr, Xe, Rn.  Then right before it are the the halogens, so another nice column: F, Cl, Br, I At (they all end in "-ine", and it's good to order them by size, because it will become useful later anyway, for studying alkyl halides and substitution reactions). Another nice part is the first and second column of the alkali metals ("s" orbitals): Li, Na, K (all +1 spectator ions that form strong bases with -OH hydronium ions), and their 2+ counterparts: Be, Mg, Ca. (You can memorize the remaining three heavier elements in each of these columns if you want to, or if you work in a firework factory ;) because they usually give nice colors when burned in a flame, so it is good to associate them with those colors when memorizing them.)  Then there's the non-metals and semi-metals part (for "p" orbitals). The first row is easy, because it's the basis for organic chemistry and life: B, C, N, O (sorted by electronegativity, and by the number of valence electrons: 3, 4, 5, 6), boron being the odd ball with incomplete octet, which makes it useful for those borohydrides that you will learn about in ochem as being good reducing agents and sources of nucleophilic hydrogens, a.k.a. hydride ions. They have their heavier cousins in the next row: Al, Si, P, S. And again, aluminum works pretty much the same as boron with that incomplete octet and hydrides (sodium borohydride, lithium aluminium hydride). Silicon is just heavier carbon, and phosphorus is just heavier nitrogen, and sulfur is just heavier oxygen, but they all have this extra ability of extending their octet if needed. You can also remember that selenium is under sulfur, if you already know that the amino acid "cysteine" contains sulfur, and its cousin "selenocysteine" contains selenium instead, because these two atoms are interchangeable due to their similar chemical properties. As for Al and Si, these are the two most abundant elements in Earth's crust, so you can group them by that. If you need the next row too, then you probably work with semiconductors ;) because here are the metals and SEMI-metals used for SEMIconductors (both start with "semi-", so there's your hint right there ;) ). Gallium is that metal that melts in your hand, used for P-type semiconductors, because it has 1 electron less than silicon or germanium; germanium is what diodes are made of, because it's just below silicon (also a semi-conductor); and arsenic is for N-type semiconductors, because it has 1 electron more than silicon or germanium. So that's a pretty big part of the periodic table (and most useful) memorized! :> If you need transition metals (with "d" orbitals) too, then again, look for patterns. All the "precious" metals (copper, silver, gold) are in one column, and it is this column that is the "exception" for the "d" orbitals (the penultimate one). Other interesting metals are flanking it: Pd and Pt on the left are the well-known catalysts; on the right: cadmium is for batteries, and mercury is the "quicksilver" liquid metal that is used in gold mining because it makes amalgams with gold. Nickel and zinc are flanking copper. Now try filling up the first row of the "d" block yourself, because this will be the most useful one. If you need more, again: learn them in columns, with "heavier cousins" of the ones from the first row, having the same chemical properties as them.
